prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for snitching on my friend (15f) to her mom, because she mentioned to me in explicit detail that she sleeps around a lot?
so there was this girl i met in one of my classes that i started talking to, as we had a lot in common, like liking the same shows, movies, hobbies, music, and what not. so as we kept talking, she told me about her previous relationships, and how she LOVES having sex, without being in a relationship, and for about a month or so i kept quiet. so we kept talking to each other, and while we mainly just talked about random nonsense, she kept going on and on about her previous relationships, and how she just broke up with her FWB, and she's now trying to get with her BFF, whos a guy. At first i honestly didn't care about her sleeping around, but i eventually tried to see it through the perspective of her mother, and I decided that I'd want to know if i were in her mums position. so when i saw her mum again ( who is also one of my teachers ) i told her in explicit detail about what her daughter has been doing, and how she lost her virginity at the age of 13. at first, her mum thought that her daughter was making up what she told me, but later started to believe me. as you can expect my ( now former) friend reacted really poorly to that, and now refuses to talk to me now. if it matters, I'm a 15 year old dude

&#x200B;

so. am i the asshole for snitching on my friend for sleeping around?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user, a 15-year-old guy, met a girl in class who they had a lot in common with. The girl talked a lot about her past relationships and her current situation with a friend who is a guy. He decided to tell her mom, who is also his teacher, the explicit details he overheard. Now the friend is mad and won't talk to him.

First, the main issue here is whether the author violated the friend's privacy. The girl shared personal information with him, and he passed it on without her consent. Even if he thought he was doing the right thing, sharing such details with her mom breaches trust. 

He mentions he considered her mom's perspective and thought the mom would want to know. But the key point is that he didn't approach the girl's mom directly to express concerns; instead, he shared the information with the mom in a way that could be seen as snitching. The girl's mom might have been in a better position to handle the situation if approached respectfully, but the author's method might have been more about his own discomfort than seeking help.

Also, the friend's reaction is understandable because personal info, especially about relationships and sex, is sensitive. The author didn't have the authority to disclose that, even if he felt it was for her own good. So, the answer is likely A, the author is in the wrong for snitching without consent.
